data.name: Tools for Managing in the New World of Work: Unlimited Vacation

data.message:
I worked for a company that transitioned to an unlimited vacation policy and it did not go over well with employees who had been there a while and worked to earn and save up vacation days. Only new employees liked it, but even then there was fear that managers would scrutinize more, and managers feared it would be more work. There was also a lot of rumors that the company was trying to sell it as a benefit to employees, when really it was benefitting the company, because it no longer had to carry the cost of accrued vacation time on its books. 

I wouldn't have expected any of these issues with a policy that sounds so cool.

data.caption: www.cornerstoneondemand.com
data.message: We're doing it, Richard Branson is doing it. Is it time for your company to adopt unlimited vacation? http://csod.info/18NuYTf
data.description: There’s been buzz lately about companies switching to unlimited vacation policies.

After spending years in an open office space, my team recently moved to a space with separate offices that ring a common lounge area. We have found that we actually interact more in the new space. 

The physical boundaries that the offices provide add a small but needed amount of formality and respect to our interactions: instead of simply talking across an open room at someone when I have a question, which may be interrupting them, and distracting other co-workers, I now have to go to someone's doorway, ask if they "have a second," and if they do, the sound of our conversation doesn't bother our colleagues. 

Rather than dreading every conversation going on around us and seeing them as possible distractions, our conversations are more meaningful. Furthermore, it is a given that if someone is hanging out/working in the common lounge area, it is acceptable to start a conversation with them without fearing that it is unwelcome...they have chosen to be "open" in that space, instead of being forced to do so. 

At first it seems counterintuitive, but  throwing up some drywall and doorways between colleagues has brought my team closer and made us more productive!

While the open office concept seems cool, modern and hip, some research suggests that it inhibits productivity and personal comfort. When it comes to the office space, does cool factor outweigh output? http://csod.info/1nrzxbZ
